data.title: The 55 Best Breakup Songs Of All Time
data.meta_description: From devastated torch songs to fist-pumping club bangers, these are the 55 greatest breakup songs of all time
data.text:
Breakups songs donâ€™t fit one simple pattern, because breakups donâ€™t fit one simple pattern. Okay, maybe they fit three or four simple patterns, but weâ€™re talking some pretty radical extremes of feeling: are you happy, are you sad? Did you dump or were you dumped? Do you want them back or do you never want to see them again?

Breakup anthems are complicated things that run the full gamut of emotion. Sadness and grief are certainly the classic ones. But some are righteous cries of joy that signal the end of a bad relationship. Others are thoughtful meditations on human connection. And othersâ€¦ well frankly theyâ€™re a little toxic, songs about burning the very concept of love to the ground.

The best breakup songs distil raw, universal human emotions into sonic symphonies. On this list, you'll find wounded soul singers and divas walking unbowed from the ashes of bad relationships. There are indignant rappers and spiteful rockers. Adele is lurking in the shadows of her ex's place, as she is wont to do. And among the 55 greatest breakup songs of all time, you're certain to find something to relate to. And if itâ€™s all too bleak, well, we've got a list of pick-me-up songs ready for you to queue up to help the healing begin.

1. â€˜Iâ€™d Rather Go Blindâ€™ by Etta James

On this stunner off 1968â€™s Tell Mama, James claims sheâ€™d prefer never being able to see again than watch her love walk away. Whatâ€™s more, she's helpless: She notices the way her man is chatting up another girl and knows right then and there that, no matter how much she cares for him, itâ€™s all over. Throw that sentiment over a simple chord progression that builds beautifully with horns, an organ, backing vocals and a heart-melting performance by James, and you've reached timeless soul perfection.

2. â€˜Somebody That I Used to Knowâ€™ by Elliott Smith

Gotye might have scored a hit with the song by the same name, but Gotye doesnâ€™t hold a flame to the heartbroken depths of Elliott Smith. Nobody does. The late-great Smith might have sung, â€˜So when I go home, Iâ€™ll be happy to go / Youâ€™re just somebody that I used to know," but he wasnâ€™t fooling anyone: This bare-bones, beautiful track is all about full-on heartache, albeit of the dismissive, fuck-you-I'm-fine variety. (For evidence, just skip to two songs later on Figure 8, â€˜Everything Reminds Me of Her.â€™)

Advertising

3. â€˜I Will Always Love Youâ€™ by Whitney Houston

Dolly Parton wrote and recorded this song in 1973 as a rueful envoi for her mentor and champion, Porter Wagoner, and later reprised it in the 1982 movie musical The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas. Although both of those versions hit the top of the country charts, the song reached its cultural apotheosis in Whitney Houston's epic 1991 version from the soundtrack to The Bodyguard; at the time, it was the best-selling American single in history. In Houston's soulful account, the song moves from a quiet, a cappella intro to a blast of gospel-inflected nobility and suffering â€“ and then drifts upward into quiet again at the very end, as though ascending to a state of grace.

4. â€˜Neither One of Usâ€™ by Gladys Knight & the Pips

Over a swelling, slow and deliberate melody, the Empress of Soul calmly and painfully recounts the end of her relationship in this heartbreaker. The song is an autopsy of a dead union as told from the perspective of a woman who has realized that love alone can't save a relationship that's gone toxic. â€˜Farewell, my love, goodbyeâ€™ she belts out at the end, with the Pips' trademark echo of the phrase lingering in the ether like the soulful moans of a lovelorn ghost.

Advertising

5. â€˜Youâ€™ve Lost That Lovinâ€™ Feelinâ€™â€™ by the Righteous Brothers

Love crashes into a wall â€“ specifically, producer Phil Spectorâ€™s trademark â€˜Wall of Soundâ€™ â€“ in this blue-eyed-soul lament, the 20th centuryâ€™s most-played song on radio and TV. Cowritten by Spector and Brill Building hit makers Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil, the song begins with a sharp observation (â€˜You never close your eyes anymore when I kiss your lipsâ€™) that leads to the chorusâ€™s pained conclusion. But the songâ€™s slowness and length â€“ in 1964, 3:45 was an eternity for radio pop â€” give it an aching tenderness that makes its final exhortation to â€˜bring back that lovin' feelinâ€™â€™ sound like it has some hope of success.

6. â€˜Someone Like Youâ€™ by Adele

Adele basically wrote the book on tear-soaked breakup ballads, and her catalog plays out like a musical tour through the stages of grief. â€˜Someone Like You,â€™ however, is Adele at her most defeated and desperate as the singer's attempt at reconnecting with a lost love meets the hard wall of reality: He's now moved on. Yes, it's a little stalkery â€“ especially as a double feature with â€˜Helloâ€™ â€“ but it's also devastating: This is the scene in the movie where the hero chases her loved one on the train platform. Only in this movie, she's left standing, alone, in the rain as he rides off into a separate happy ending.

Advertising

7. â€˜All Too Well (10-Minute Version) by Taylor Swift

On the original cut of Red, â€˜All Too Wellâ€™ was a torch song about young love gone sour. But when a post folklore Taylor revisited the album as an older and wiser songwriter in 2021, she ditched the torch in favor of a flamethrower. Clocking in at a breathless 10 minutes, the new version of â€˜All Too Wellâ€™ finds Swiftâ€™s animosity over the heartbreak endured when she was 21 curdled into righteous resentment as she goes into extreme detail about her former beauâ€™s duplicitous charms, manipulations and deceptions. In extending the song, Taylor transformed a fan favorite into a haunting masterpiece, and while sheâ€™s never confirmed who itâ€™s about, itâ€™s probably an awkward time to be an actor whose name rhymes with â€˜rake spillinâ€™ ball.â€™

8. â€˜Back to Blackâ€™ by Amy Winehouse

The late singer-songwriter crooned plenty about addiction, depression and heartbreak, but nowhere more brutally than in this moody torch song, which gave its title to her 2007 album. Winehouse penned this hit single about her falling back into bad habits after her very public break with husband Blake Fielder-Civil. The gloomy repetition of the word black during the bridge is the sound of a spiral into darkness â€“ albeit a funky one.

Advertising

9. â€˜The Tracks of My Tearsâ€™ by Smokey Robinson and the Miracles

Smokey might, indeed, â€˜be the life of the party,â€™ but â€˜deep inside [he's] blue,â€™ people. As with the best soulful weepers, â€˜Tracksâ€™ beautifully and economically articulates the pain of missing the one that got away. This summer-of-â€™65 staple â€“ a cocktail of Smokeyâ€™s golden voice, swirling strings and horns, and a sing-along-worthy chorus â€“ rings just as true today.

10. â€˜Ex-Factorâ€™ by Lauryn Hill

â€˜Doo Wop (That Thing)â€™ may have been the flagship single from Lauryn Hillâ€™s post-Fugees solo debut â€“ 1998â€™s multi-Grammy-winning The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill â€“ but it was the languid, lovely â€˜Ex-Factorâ€™ that rocketed the disc into the realms of extraordinary. Perfectly piquant down to the name of the song, â€˜Ex-Factorâ€™ longs for things to be different while knowing they canâ€™t be, ringing with frustration (â€˜I keep letting you back inâ€™) but humming with a love that refuses to fade.

Advertising

11. â€˜You Oughta Knowâ€™ by Alanis Morissette

Whether sheâ€™s snarling at a former Full House star is irrelevant: Alanisâ€™s searing, angry breakout is a primal scream of a scorned lover, and lines like â€˜And every time I scratch my nails down someone elseâ€™s back I hope you feel itâ€™ are relatable to anyone who's ever wanted to set fire to an entire relationship and watch it burn.

12. â€˜Itâ€™s Too Lateâ€™ by Carole King

Carole Kingâ€™s era-shaping 1971 album, Tapestry, was in some sense a declaration of independence from Gerry Goffin, her former husband and songwriting collaborator. The albumâ€™s first single, â€˜Itâ€™s Too Late,â€™ treats the end of a once-cherished relationship with bittersweet maturity, strength and striking lack of recrimination: â€˜Still Iâ€™m glad for what we had / And how I once loved you.â€™ Itâ€™s a song about being realistic about the end â€“ a sentiment made all the more moving by its initial pairing, as a single, with the tremblingly erotic â€˜I Feel the Earth Move.â€™

Advertising

13. â€˜Mapsâ€™ by Yeah Yeah Yeahs

The enduring force of the Yeah Yeah Yeahsâ€™s most classic song lies in its expression of the inexpressible: the pithy, repetitive lyrics (â€˜Oh say, oh say, oh say... waitâ€™) capturing that tongue-tied desperation between denial and acceptance. And as if Karen Oâ€™s weepy performance in the music video wasn't already affecting enough â€“ the singer revealed that the tears were entirely genuine, motivated by her then-boyfriend (for whom she wrote the song) showing up to the shoot.

14. â€˜thank u, nextâ€™ by Ariana Grande

Following your breakup with a hit single thanking each and every one of your past flames for the lessons learned from those relationships? The phrase â€˜above itâ€™ hardly seems sufficient for this refreshingly resentment-free ode to moving on. Ariana teaches us all what it means to go out with grace on this suprise-release earworm thatâ€™s packed with a surprising amount of wisdom.

Advertising

15. â€˜Pain In My Heartâ€™ by Otis Redding

Over and again, whether hopeful or heartbreaking, Otis Reddingâ€™s exquisite love songs bring us to our knees, like this title track off the soul iconâ€™s 1964 debut album for Stax Records subdivision Volt (which also includes the imploring â€˜These Arms of Mineâ€™). If youâ€™re really in the mood to wallow, mourn the fact that Redding perished in a plane crash at age 26, just three days after recording â€˜Dock of the Bay.â€™

16. â€˜I Will Surviveâ€™ by Gloria Gaynor

Is there any song that combines female empowerment and discofied schmaltz with the same efficacy as Gloria Gaynorâ€™s â€˜I Will Survive?â€™ Probably not: With lyrics like â€˜Iâ€™ve got all my life to live / Iâ€™ve got all my love to give / And Iâ€™ll survive, I will surviveâ€™ sang over a soaring melody accented by horns and strings galore, this is the epitome of disco-ball empowerment In fact, we think the Grammy-winning hit, released in late 1978, is one of the best â€˜screw you, loser â€“ Iâ€™m over youâ€™ tunes of all time.

Advertising

17. â€˜How Can You Mend a Broken Heartâ€™ by Al Green

Look, just because youâ€™ve had your heart broken, it doesnâ€™t mean that your mojo has to wilt away and die too â€“ and the Reverend Al is here to spell that out via his definitive 1972 version of the Bee Gees cut. He aches just like you, but his hope hasnâ€™t died â€“ â€˜Please help me mend my broken heart / And let me live againâ€™ ) â€“ and Alâ€™s signature slow, sensual soul arrangements prove that it's not just his heart thatâ€™s stirring.

18. â€˜Tangled Up in Blueâ€™ by Bob Dylan

Jakob Dylan once said that listening to his fatherâ€™s 1975 album, Blood on the Tracks, was like listening to his parents fighting. You can hear why on its opening track, â€˜Tangled Up in Blueâ€™ â€“ a song that feels lived-in, true and intimate, and at the same time assumes an Odyssean quality. Inspired by Dylanâ€™s split from his wife Sara, the song finds our narrator caught between throw-in-the-towel resignation and deep, soul-shuddering longing: tangled up in blue.

Advertising

19. â€˜Hey, Thatâ€™s No Way to Say Goodbyeâ€™ by Leonard Cohen

Troubadour Cohen has many a song in his arsenal to reduce grown adults to pathetic wistfulness, but this 1967 beauty is the most effective of them all. Its setup is simple â€“ two lovers remember the happy times even as they part, via Cohenâ€™s sweet, sad lyrics: â€˜You know my love goes with you as your love stays with me / Itâ€™s just the way it changes, like the shoreline and the sea.â€™ What makes it a classic, however, is how upbeat Cohenâ€™s picked guitar, mouth harp and evocative similes feel against the reality of the situation, deftly demonstrating that losing someone can be painful but cathartic.

20. â€˜Irreplaceableâ€™ by BeyoncÃ©

The Destiny's Child songbook is a bible for the woman looking to keep her man on his toes. Just in case â€˜Bills, Bills, Bills,â€™ â€˜Say My Nameâ€™ and â€˜Survivorâ€™ didn't send a clear enough message, BeyoncÃ© reiterated her â€˜Donâ€™t get too comfortableâ€™ party line on this, the ultimate kick-you-to-the-curb anthem. The singer doesnâ€™t sound the slightest bit perturbed as she shoos a disappointing lover out of her crib, advising him that heâ€™ll find his worldly possessions â€˜in a box to the left.â€™

Advertising

21. â€˜Dancing on My Ownâ€™ by Robyn

The ultimate sad banger and Swedish avant-popster Robynâ€™s finest hour, â€˜Dancing on My Ownâ€™ is equal parts melancholia and euphoria. Its lyrics about staring despondently at an ex copping off with a new squeeze are caught up in glitteringly danceable synth lines â€“ â€˜Dancing On My Ownâ€™ is about defiantly keeping your chin up in the face of romantic misfortune as much as it is about feeling sorry for yourself.

22. â€˜Always on My Mindâ€™ by Willie Nelson

Itâ€™s been a hit for other artists â€“ notably Elvis Presley and the Pet Shop Boys â€“ but â€˜Always on My Mindâ€™ has never packed more wallop than in Willie Nelsonâ€™s recording, the title track of his eponymous 1982 album. Humble and sincere, Nelsonâ€™s plea for forgiveness exudes the quiet wisdom of genuine contrition: Having finally opened his eyes, he allows himself to hope that they can still make contact.

Advertising

23. â€˜Cryingâ€™ by Roy Orbison

Roy Orbisonâ€™s 1961 ballad is sensitive almost to a fault: the confession of a total bawler, reduced to tears even by touching the hand of the woman who broke his heart. But the emotion soaked into Orbisonâ€™s rich, quavering voice is offset by the singerâ€™s disciplined, deadpan cool. Even when baring his sobbing soul, he somehow seems unflappable.

24. â€˜Don't Speakâ€™ by No Doubt

This one from 1996â€™s Tragic Kingdom, which Gwen Stefani penned in response to her breakup with bandmate Tony Kanal, became the bandâ€™s most successful international single â€“ and a rallying cry for lovelorn souls the world over to go right ahead and bury their head in the sand.

Advertising

25. â€˜I Just Donâ€™t Know What to Do With Myselfâ€™ by the White Stripes

Though this song was originally sung by Tommy Hunt in 1962 (and has since been covered by myriad musicians, including Dusty Springfield, Dionne Warwick, Isaac Hayes and Elvis Costello), no one has been able to capture the desperation â€“ and frustration â€“ behind the lyrics quite like Jack White. Recorded for the 2003 White Stripes release Elephant, this rock & roll version is perfect for the transition from heartbroken to pissed off.

26. â€˜Without Youâ€™ by Harry Nilsson

Always pushing his liver and vocal cords to the limit, Nilsson injected histrionics and heart into the songs he covered as if it were HGH. His take on Randy Newmanâ€™s â€˜Living Without Youâ€™ is downbeat perfect. Fact: It is impossible to listen to this Kleenex-consuming epic without balling your hands into fists and mock-karaokeing along. Next song on the album? â€˜Coconut.â€™ Drink the pain away.

Advertising

27. â€˜Riverâ€™ by Joni Mitchell

A broken heart isn't just for those who've been broken up with â€“ as â€˜Riverâ€™ attests. It's a breakup anthem that sounds as crisp and sad-in-the-bones today as it did when it was released as part of Joni Mitchellâ€™s perfectly titled Blue album in 1971. â€˜I'm so hard to handle, I'm selfish and I'm sad, now I've gone and lost the best baby that I ever had,â€™ sings Mitchell, then later: â€˜I made my baby say goodbye.â€™ The song is thought to have been written about Mitchell's decision to end her relationship with Graham Nash â€“ who in turn released his astonishingly tender Songs for Beginners album. Both records are generous gifts for anyone nursing a wounded heart.

28. â€˜I Heard It Through the Grapevineâ€™ by Marvin Gaye

You know even before the drumbeat kicks in that something is gonna go down in this song. And for anyone whoâ€™s had to hear the cheatinâ€™, lyinâ€™ news from someone else, this 1968 Motown single hits home. Itâ€™s become an acclaimed, Grammy Hall of Fame soul classic, covered by a range of musicians including Creedence Clearwater Revival (which made an 11-minute version for its 1970 album Cosmoâ€™s Factory) and claymation group the California Raisins. (Grapevine, raisins â€“ see what they did there?) But nobody will ever match Marvinâ€™s signature mix of vulnerabilty, indignation and pain.

Advertising

29. â€˜End of the Roadâ€™ by Boyz II Men

Unlike Gladys, the Philly hitmakers simply canâ€™t let go of the relationship they know is inevitably ending. The worst part is, after all the soulful pleas for things to go on, one gets the impression that the quartet is very much singing to somebody whoâ€™s already turned their back to walk into the sunset.

30. â€˜Rosesâ€™ by Outkast

This admonishing ode to Caroline appeared on Andre 300â€™'s half of Outkastâ€™s 2003 double album, Speakerboxxx/The Love Below. It quickly achieved anthem status, thanks in no small part to Andreâ€™s unapologetically frank (if a bit misogynistic) lyrics. Letâ€™s be honest, sometimes cuties get away with bad behavior, but there are limits, and when your love interest crosses them, â€˜Rosesâ€™ is the perfect way to tell them to piss off.

Advertising

31. â€˜Teardropsâ€™ by Womack & Womack

A classic in the genre of Songs to Cry to in Clubs, this 1988 electrodisco anthem tells the tale of a cheating heart haunted by its infidelity. â€˜Footsteps on the dance floor / Remind me, baby of you / Teardrops in my eyes / Next time, Iâ€™ll be true.â€™ This silky cut comes from Cecil (brother of Bobby) Womack and his wife, Linda â€“ a formidable musical partnership throughout the â€™80s and â€™90s. This is their biggest and best hit, however, and responsible for plenty tear-stained dancing shoes over the years.

32. â€˜Hide and Seekâ€™ by Imogen Heap

Prog-popstress Imogen Heap toes the line between poignantly lachrymose and sickeningly maudlin â€“ so itâ€™s unsurprising her most heartachey song was immortalized in the climactic scene to a season of The O.C.. From there, the indie tune took a viral turn, rocketing from an SNL Andy Samberg sketch straight into the top charts by-way of a Jason Derulo sample. That is to say: if these forlorn folktronica vocal harmonies are sad enough for the cast of The O.C., SNL and Jason Derulo, theyâ€™re sad enough to soundtrack your boring breakup.

Advertising

33. â€˜Blame Gameâ€™ by Kanye West

With an Aphex Twin sample, West balanced anger, pain and smartassery like no other MC can. Itâ€™s touching. That is, if you turn it off before Chris Rock comes in for the perplexing coda, exclaiming, â€™This is some Cirque du Soleil pussy now!â€™ for reasons unknown. By the next album, Yeezus would be a married man, grudge-rapping about fisting and ejaculating on fine fur coats before eventually finding Jesus.

34. â€˜Walk On Byâ€™ by Dionne Warwick

The 1960s songwriting team of Burt Bacharach and Hal David found their perfect interpreter in Dionne Warwick, whose breezy style made the duoâ€™s character-driven, rhythmically challenging tunes sound deceptively simple. In 1964's â€˜Walk on By,â€™ one of her first Bacharach-David hits, Warwick teases out the smooth dignity in a song about the pain of rejection.

Advertising

35. â€˜Un-Break My Heartâ€™ by Toni Braxton

Queen of '90s R&B heartache, Toni Braxton delivered more than just another sad love song when â€˜Un-Break My Heartâ€™ hit the airwaves in 1996. A mÃ©lange of Spanish guitars and Braxtonâ€™s sultry contralto vocals, the Grammy-winning single builds a quiet storm with a dramatic crescendo as Braxton pleads with her ex to rewind their doomed relationship back to happier times. If the songâ€™s video is any indication, those happier times included playing Twister and sharing a shower with hunky model Tyson Beckford. So, yeah, we feel ya, Toni.

36. â€˜Marvins Roomâ€™ by Drake

Who hasnâ€™t been faced off of rosÃ©, drunk dialing the one that got away? In the lead single from 2011â€™s Take Care, the Toronto hip-hip lord lays bare his romantic struggles over a stripped-down, wafting beat. At the time, it cemented Drakeâ€™s status as the reigning king of emo rap.

Advertising

37. â€˜Go Your Own Wayâ€™ by Fleetwood Mac

From one of rockâ€™s most painful breakups came one of rockâ€™s greatest breakup songs. The fallout from Lindsey Buckinghamâ€™s split with Stevie Nicks in 1976 may have made the recording of Rumours a living hell for its creators, but who cares? It spawned one of the most defiant and furious songs of a generation. No pain, no gain.

38. â€˜Wrecking Ballâ€™ by Miley Cyrus

More than a billion YouTubers have dropped their jaws at the Terry Richardsonâ€“directed video for Miley Cyrus's power ballad, in which a naked Cyrus straddling a massive steel ball. All snickers and parody videos aside, the track stands on its own as essential listening for dumpers and dumpees who have gone full-tilt into relationships and wound up emotionally demolished. And the racy video antics? Well, as BFF Lesley told us long ago, sheâ€™s just being Miley.

Advertising

39. â€˜Nothing Compares 2 Uâ€™ by Sinead Oâ€™Connor

Originally written and composed by Prince, â€˜Nothing Compares 2 Uâ€™ didnâ€™t reach iconic, heart-decimating status until a certain headstrong Irish singer-songwriter tried her hand â€“ and those sad, sad eyes â€“ at covering it in 1990. The video, which alternates between a stark close-up of Oâ€™Connor's despair-wrought face and shots of the dark-cloaked songstress roaming through Paris's Parc de Saint-Cloud, was cited by Miley Cyrus as the inspiration for her 2013 â€˜Wrecking Ballâ€™ video. It canâ€™t be denied that three decades later, Oâ€™Connorâ€™s wrenching rendition still packs a punch.

40. â€˜Sheâ€™s Goneâ€™ by Hall & Oates

Like the haunted mirror image of â€˜You Make My Dreamsâ€™ â€“ or perhaps a follow up after the dream ended â€“ â€˜She's Goneâ€™ proves that even on the yacht of life, stormy skies will rock your boat.

Advertising

41. â€˜Switchâ€™ by TLC

The penultimate track on TLC's lauded sophomore effort finds the R&B high priestesses telling possessive lovers to shove off over a groovy flip of Jean Knightâ€™s â€˜Mr. Big Stuff.â€™ The album, CrazySexyCool, went diamond, rocketing Tionne â€˜T-Bozâ€™ Watkins, Lisa â€˜Left Eyeâ€™ Lopes and Rozonda â€˜Chilliâ€™ Thomas into superstardom. Any time your paramour has you feeling a little claustrophobic, just remember Left Eyeâ€™s mantra: Erase, replace, embrace, new face.

42. â€˜Togetherâ€™ by Ruff Sqwad feat. Wiley

What does a grime break-up song sound like? Pair OG grime pioneers Ruff Sqwad with the legendary Eskiboy and youâ€™ve got yourself a break-up banger. Rapping over Ruff Sqwadâ€™s original â€˜Togetherâ€™ (which samples the very familiar guitar rift from the Policeâ€™s â€˜Message in a Bottleâ€™), Wiley teases repeatedly with the rhetorical question, â€˜(When we gonna) be together?â€™ He fills in his verses with strong punches at his ex-lover, providing the harsh reality of things and quickly becoming his own hype man as he promises to only do better for himself. Listen to Wiley: Don't wallow in self-pity.

Advertising

43. â€˜Cry Me a Riverâ€™ by Julie London

This devastating torch song was written for Ella Fitzgerald in 1953, but Julie London managed to release it before the Queen of Jazz was able to get a version out. It became Londonâ€™s signature song: Backed by a late-night thrum of guitar and bass that teeters ambiguously between the minor and major keys, her hushed vocals waver between tender, haughty and devastated.

44. â€˜Since U Been Goneâ€™ by Kelly Clarkson

You may hate American Idol. You may hate pop. You may hate it when people use u instead of you. But hereâ€™s the deal: You may also really hate your ex. And this song (off of Clarksonâ€™s 2004 album, Breakaway) is so goddamned catchy, you canâ€™t not belt out the chorus every time â€“ with feeling.

Advertising

45. â€˜I Want You Backâ€™ by the Jackson 5

What the hell does an 11 year old know about loss? With a tip of his giant purple pimp hat, Michael sang this Motown peak with a mile-wide smile on Ed Sullivan in â€™69. Still, the kid sold it like nobody else, over chords that rise and fall like a roller coaster. And nothing hurts like first love.

46. â€˜I'm So Happyâ€™ by Salem Al Fakir & Josephine Bornebusch

Most breakup songs are drenched in sadness. This peppy, almost painfully joyous dose of Swedish bubblegum indie finds Al Fakir positively elated to see his partner go, interlacing lines like â€˜Iâ€™m so happy, cuz you are gone/You are gone, it makes me happyâ€™ with sing-songy â€˜la la laâ€™ riffs, just to ensure the subject doesn't misinterpret the very-difficult-to-misconstrue lyrics.

Advertising

47. â€˜Tornâ€™ by Natalie Imbruglia

Lurking behind the glossy sheen and shimmering guitars of this 1997 global pop hit is the age-old story of a relationship gone sour. â€˜Tornâ€™ was originally recorded by American alt rockers Ednaswap, but saucy Aussie Natalie Imbrugliaâ€™s rendition perfectly encapsulates the unhappy transition from honeymoon optimism to the realization that â€˜Illusion never changed into something real.â€™ Seriously, we totally hate it when that happens.

48. â€˜Just a Friendâ€™ by Biz Markie

RIP to the Biz, whose most famous hip hop track found him spinning a lovely, tragic tale about a girl named Blah Blah Blah who plunked the big teddy bear directly in the friend zone, only to break his heart irreparably. Whether Blah Blah Blah thought of this as a breakup song is a Rashomon situation we'll alas never see, but Biz's pained delivery shows that regardless, the scars were everlasting.

Advertising

49. â€˜Dry Your Eyesâ€™ by the Streets

Menâ€™s emotions can sometimes be harder to read than a pureed copy of Proust. In 2004, however, the Streetsâ€™a Mike Skinner just laid it right on the line. While Skinnerâ€™s verses found him crestfallen at having been chucked, itâ€™s the choruses that made the tune so beloved, delivering man-to-man comfort and kindly reassurances that there are â€˜plenty more fish in the sea.â€™

50. â€˜Believeâ€™ by Cher

If you donâ€™t think this is a brilliant song, then itâ€™s probably only because youâ€™ve heard it way too many times. Cherâ€™s (temporary) resurrection as a dance-pop diva in 1998 has raised plenty of hackles over the years â€“ not least for its then-unprecedented use of Auto-Tune â€“ but at its heart itâ€™s simply a great breakup song in the air-punchingly empowered tradition of â€˜I Will Surviveâ€™: â€˜Iâ€™ve had time to think it through / And maybe Iâ€™m too good for you.â€™ When weâ€™re going through a rough time, we could all use a bit of that attitude.

Advertising

51. â€˜Back for Goodâ€™ by Take That

The legendary British boyband never really cracked the US, but they did strike a universal chord â€“ and their only American hit â€“ with this tour de force breakup ballad. Itâ€™s a classic soaring pop ballad, but itâ€™s Gary Barlowâ€™s devastatingly perceptive lyrics about wanted to be taken back by a lover who has moved on that really make it: â€˜in the twist of separation, you excelled at being freeâ€™.

52. â€˜Blackâ€™ by Pearl Jam

Released at the height of Pearl Jamâ€™s media-distrusting early fame, frontman Eddie Vedder has never publicly commented on who â€˜Blackâ€™ is written about. But boy, did we feel his pain about the breakup. A dirge that would be comically overwrought if it werenâ€™t so devastatingly heartfelt, it builds over more than five minutes of oft abstract lyricism to Vedderâ€™s final, anguished roar to his ex: â€˜I know someday you'll have a beautiful life, I know you'll be a star In somebody else's sky, but whyâ€¦ can't it be mine?â€™

Advertising

53. â€˜Cry Me a Riverâ€™ by Justin Timberlake

Ooooookay the video in which Timberlake wanders around the apartment of an actress who looks remarkably like his ex Britney Spears isâ€¦ problematic these days.
